title-group.article-title: The manufacture of an international news event: The day Kosovo was born

author-notes.corresp: Chris Paterson, Institute of Communications Studies, University of Leeds, Leeds LS2 9JT, UK Email: c.paterson@leeds.ac.uk

fn.p: Chris Paterson is a Senior Lecturer for Broadcast Journalism in the Institute of Communications Studies of the University of Leeds, where he directs the MA in International Journalism. His research concerns the production and flow of international news, online news, and news agencies, and he was a founding coordinator of the IAMCR Working Group for Media Production Analysis.

Kenneth Andresen is an Assistant Professor of Journalism at the Gimlekollen School of Journalism and Communication in Norway. He has taught journalism courses in Kosovo since 1999. His research focuses on news production in post-war areas and international media support. He is also a co-author of a radio journalism textbook.

Abit Hoxha is a Media and Communications Specialist. He has worked in various government and non-government institutions in Kosovo in the field of Missing Persons, Return and Refugees, and Capacity Development in the Kosovo Security Sector with UNDP Kosovo. He earned his first degree in Political Science in 2005 from the University of Prishtina in Kosovo and an MA degree from the Kosovo Institute of Journalism and Communications in 2007. He is the author of Reporting in Kosovo: War and Post-War (VDM Verlag, 2010).

abstract.p: When the new country of Kosovo declared its independence in 2008 it received extensive, but fleeting, international news coverage. This study seeks to provide insight into how an international news event was orchestrated by participants and how news coverage was planned and implemented by international media. We do so by investigating factors initiating, enabling, shaping, and limiting the global news coverage of this story. Particular attention is paid to the close relationship between local ‘fixers’ and media representatives, which is instrumental in most international news coverage, but which has received little scholarly examination; and to the influential role of the UK-based international television news agencies.
